SEARCH
Package emissary.core

Class Factory

java.lang.Object
emissary.core.Factory
public class Factory extends Object
Factory.create() is one of the main methods that Emissary uses. This method simply constructs objects in the server name space so they may be referred to. Since this implementation is intended to run on a single machine, the create() method simply uses reflection (i.e. Class.forname() and Constructor.newInstance) to create the specified object. In the cases where a name (or handle) is supplied with the constructor arguments, the Namespace.bind method is called to save a reference to the object with that name.
Author:
ce
See Also:
  • Namespace.bind(java.lang.String, java.lang.Object)

  • Method Details

    • create

      public static Object create(String className, Object... args)
      Create an object from it's classname using args for arguments
      Parameters:
      className - the string classname to get a new instance of
      args - the arguments to a public constructor of classname
      Returns:
      The newly instantiated object. If it cannot instantiate, this throws some sort of Exception/Error.

    • create

      public static Object create(String className)
      Create an object of the type specified using a no-arg constructor
      Parameters:
      className - the string class name to instantiate
      Returns:
      The newly instantiated object. If it cannot instantiate, this throws some sort of Exception/Error.

    • create

      public static Object create(String className, Object[] args, String location)
      Create an object and bind it into the namespace
      Parameters:
      className - the string classname to get a new instance of
      args - the arguments to a public constructor of classname
      location - name used to bind into the namespace
      Returns:
      the newly instantiated object

    • createV

      public static Object createV(String className, String location, Object... args)
      Create an object and bind it into the namespace. This method is used to prevent the ambiguity around overloaded varargs methods.
      Parameters:
      className - the string classname to get a new instance of
      location - name used to bind into the namespace
      args - the arguments to a public constructor of classname
      Returns:
      the newly instantiated object
